body:
> If you don't want to lose history, there is an `old_name` field available which will allow you keep the history https://concourse-ci.org/jobs.html#schema.job.old_name
> 
> I used it on my current teams concourse when fixing deprecation warnings and it worked well for us. It also exists for resources

I should add that to keep folk happy.

@rhoughton-pivot also forgot to mention that fly has a command for rename pipeline https://concourse-ci.org/managing-pipelines.html#fly-rename-pipeline to preserve pipeline history if changing the pipeline name.  Might be harder to do with automation, but it also should be a one time thing

On second look, the way we have the jobs templated, we can't use any simple Jinja tricks to modify the names and keep the old ones, and the full rename-effort is not worth it for the sake of history. Any artifacts are uploaded to GCS as needed anyway.
the dunit failures are known issues

This pull request **introduces 2 alerts** when merging bdb1894531c8e35c8300a5f6fbe9ac40b06c43af into 6702402a98de98c61b71d9d017c863dc659acf0c - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/apache/geode/rev/pr-4dd2ed64cb44e028dba4bed878034eea3f42a4bb)

**new alerts:**

* 1 for Use of a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm
* 1 for Potential input resource leak

Regarding the set copying that Dan mentioned, I agree that it's something we want to avoid and get rid of, but the sets used in the diff and intersection operations need to be a class that can handle comparisons between byte arrays in the way we want. However, returning a `ObjectOpenCustomHashSet` from the lambdas in `RedisSetCommandsFunctionExecutor.internalsmembers()` or `RedisSetCommandsFunctionExecutor.smembers()` results in serialization filter errors, so as a compromise, this set copying behaviour is used to allow a `HashSet` to be returned from the lambda and then turned back into a `ObjectOpenCustomHashSet` when needed for diff and intersection. Since these commands aren't currently supported, this bevaiour should be revisited when they're fully implemented and supported.

> Looks solid. I think that @upthewaterspout's comments are valuable, but given the scope of this ticket, I think it would be better to add something to Jira to track that work.

Agreed. I'll create a ticket.

As an fyi, the geode native gemfiles don't specify the version of bookbindery, so you just need to update the lock files

Without explicit version of elasticsearch in Gemfile, it is updated from 7.3.0 to 7.13.0 when executing `bundle install`.
And `elasticsearch 7.13.0` has a dependency on `faraday >= 1.0`, but `sendgrid-ruby 1.1.6` has a dependency on `faraday < 1`

Hi @DonalEvans and all,

Thanks for the review!

Regarding your question whether it is possible to check on receiving member if is notification only. I have already tried that with previous commit https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/6477/commits/b3dbf5024dd378ef1bbb48658cf02500b6cff6c9  which broke design base case explained in this comment: https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/6477#issuecomment-846037604

Beside above solution I was considering another alternative solution on receiving member. When TXCommitMessage is received on member which doesn't host targeted bucket (only subscription queue) then part of code within following if statement is executed :

https://github.com/apache/geode/blob/be1fad39c4f7291ad37051ba1e59046f8c52537e/geode-core/src/main/java/org/apache/geode/internal/cache/TXCommitMessage.java#L1300

Impact (set TailKey to -1) could be done within to avoid putting the event in parallel gateway sender temporary queue. I haven't done it because I was unsure of the case that is described in following comment (open link since it has multiple lines):

https://github.com/apache/geode/blob/be1fad39c4f7291ad37051ba1e59046f8c52537e/geode-core/src/main/java/org/apache/geode/internal/cache/TXCommitMessage.java#L1323

In comment it is stated that this part of code can be also reached while data bucket (colocated parallel gateway-sender queue bucket is always created after data bucket) is being created and `TXCommitMessage` message is received. I couldn't been able to get this case, and I'm not sure that it is possible. I tried to execute transactions before member requests for data bucket `InitialImageOperation$RequestRVVMessage` (this is done even before GII) and in this case `if (this.internalRegion instanceof PartitionedRegion)` condition is not fulfilled because targeted BucketRegion is at this point of time already created and therefore `internalRegion` variable is of type `BucketRegion` and not `PartitionedRegion`.

Based on all above, at least to me, it seems that impact could be created on receiving member. Also I guess that even if it happens that some parallel gateway-sender events are ignored in period before` InitialImageOperation$RequestRVVMessage` (for data bucket region) everything should be fine, because these gateway-sender events should be transferred later on in initial image for colocated gateway-sender queue bucket.

To be honest I'm not experienced in this part and I'm probably missing something. What do you think? Is this better solution? Any other suggestion is welcome.

> please also change `_` to `-` in the three benchmarks jobs names for consistency, and update .asf.yaml as well (even though the copy on develop is not yet the source of truth, it will eventually overwrite what's on master when 1.15.0 is released)

Done. Please re-review.

is it possible to update spotless rules to require/enforce use of curly braces going forward?

> is it possible to update spotless rules to require/enforce use of curly braces going forward?

I think it should be possible to check, although I'm not too familiar with how spotless works. It's certainly possible to construct a regex that identifies control flow statements without curly braces, but ensuring there are no false positives might be tricky.

Tagging @kirklund for a re-review or to continue the discussion, since his concerns may have been addressed at this point.

@mivanac 
>> I have explained use case for this PR. If community is not interested in such change, I will close this PR.

Its not community is interested or not; it is the nature of the problem that could raise many questions/concerns and its effectiveness that could bring different views and could take time to resolve (for good). If you can see many community members are involved here trying to get to an optimal conclusion.
Looking at the problem and the solution proposed; this problem seems to be a good candidate to raise an RFC, where discussion could have been carried out to understand the pros and cons of the issue and solutions.
From the problem description it seems you are trying to address performance issue with client connection. It would have been nice to see, what kind of performance impact we are looking at (e.g. with prototype)
Because of the sensitive nature of the issue (use/exposure of a n/w info) it will be nice to talked about any security issues that this could bring about.
As I mentioned above; some of the areas that could have been discussed in RFC are:
- Benefits (with some sample perf number)
- Security concerns/issues with this
- Case where an external client tries to fetch the internal info (outside of k8 env - what happens in this case) 
- How other client connection could be impacted or can use similar in future (Java, C++, JMX, Gfsh, pulse connections)
- Requirement for Backward compatibility,  rolling upgrade tests (I am not seeing any here)
good catch, looks like this problem was only introduced about a week ago
since this is a fix to GEODE-9284 perhaps that would be a more appropriate ticket number than GEODE-4826?

the dunit failure is the known issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-9242

For clarity, the failures in distributed-test-openjdk8 are GEODE-9038 and GEODE-5304, and the failure in acceptance-test-openjdk11 is GEODE-9252. All of these are known issues/flaky tests and not related to the changes in this PR.

> This looks like an additional dependency, not a version bump. From

json-smart is used by json-path, not directly by Geode.  you can check `./gradlew :geode-management:dependencies` or the contents of any previous release to confirm that json-path brings in 2.3 by default.  since there is no newer version of json-path available that might bring in the updated json-smart, the only option is to override the version here.
Were this a new dependency, you would expect to also see it newly referenced in at least one gradle file...

> Were this a new dependency, you would expect to also see it newly referenced in at least one gradle file...

Makes sense. Thanks!

@DonalEvans the stress new test failures are, for example: `expected <295.855182098051[84]> but was:<295.855182098051[96]>`. so that's why I had close to in that test. I guess I thought that that difference was a reasonable margin of error. but the 5% that I had in there is way too forgiving. So I think I'll add back the "close to" with a much smaller offset.

> @DonalEvans the stress new test failures are, for example: `expected <295.855182098051[84]> but was:<295.855182098051[96]>`. so that's why I had close to in that test. I guess I thought that that difference was a reasonable margin of error. but the 5% that I had in there is way too forgiving. So I think I'll add back the "close to" with a much smaller offset.

Hmm. Do we know why the numbers aren't matching up exactly? If it's just a test issue then using "close to" is fine as a workaround, but I think it would be good to know exactly what's happening first, in case this is pointing to a possible issue in the implementation.

> > @DonalEvans the stress new test failures are, for example: `expected <295.855182098051[84]> but was:<295.855182098051[96]>`. so that's why I had close to in that test. I guess I thought that that difference was a reasonable margin of error. but the 5% that I had in there is way too forgiving. So I think I'll add back the "close to" with a much smaller offset.
> 
> Hmm. Do we know why the numbers aren't matching up exactly? If it's just a test issue then using "close to" is fine as a workaround, but I think it would be good to know exactly what's happening first, in case this is pointing to a possible issue in the implementation.

I think that the numbers don't quite match because floating point math is hard for computers. it's accurate to a lot of decimal places. also native redis doesn't pass the test for equality. but they both pass with an offset of 0.00000001. I think that's pretty reasonable.

> > > @DonalEvans the stress new test failures are, for example: `expected <295.855182098051[84]> but was:<295.855182098051[96]>`. so that's why I had close to in that test. I guess I thought that that difference was a reasonable margin of error. but the 5% that I had in there is way too forgiving. So I think I'll add back the "close to" with a much smaller offset.
> > 
> > 
> > Hmm. Do we know why the numbers aren't matching up exactly? If it's just a test issue then using "close to" is fine as a workaround, but I think it would be good to know exactly what's happening first, in case this is pointing to a possible issue in the implementation.
> 
> I think that the numbers don't quite match because floating point math is hard for computers. it's accurate to a lot of decimal places. also native redis doesn't pass the test for equality. but they both pass with an offset of 0.00000001. I think that's pretty reasonable.

Ah, if native Redis also fails with `isEqualTo()` then I'm not too concerned. An offset that small is pretty strong, so yeah, seems good.

> I hate to ask, because it's an absolutely enormous class, but are there other places here where this fix could be preemptively applied? If it could all be fixed in one go rather than as each test happens to get unlucky and fail, that would be great.

Previously I was searching by calls to TxManager.commit(), for this PR I searched for calls to TxManager.begin() and identified where we try to work on the same transaction in two invoke() calls without properly suspending/resuming the transaction.

@upthewaterspout Initially, I thought it was redundant, but have restored it and reworked it somewhat. It showed up a problem with future `MOVED` work that is based on this PR. So thanks for that prompt!

> Having thought about these changes some more, I'm wondering if it's necessary to be quite so strict with the Geode version check (such as in IndexRepositoryFactory and LuceneEventListener). Certainly on the current develop branch, any older version of Geode will cause problems if a Lucene query is attempted, but once 1.15.0 has been released, there should be no problem with rolling from 1.15.0 to a newer version, providing the Lucene version hasn't changed again. It might be better to instead check that there is no member older than the version in which Lucene was updated (1.15.0, assuming we don't cut the release branch before these changes are merged). I understand that this would be more work, and would mean that RollingUpgrade tests would become more complex, as they'd have to cover both the failing and passing cases, but if you agree that there would be value in only preventing Lucene queries when we know there's a potential problem rather than the more blunt approach currently used, then I'd appreciate the change.

Yes, there should no be a problem with rolling upgrade to a newer version once 1.15.0 is released, until there are no format changes in new Lucene versions. 
Maybe we can change tests to have some check to see if there is a member older than 1.15.0, and regarding the result run query or ignore it until all members are on a version where Lucene was updated, or newer.

> > Having thought about these changes some more, I'm wondering if it's necessary to be quite so strict with the Geode version check (such as in IndexRepositoryFactory and LuceneEventListener). Certainly on the current develop branch, any older version of Geode will cause problems if a Lucene query is attempted, but once 1.15.0 has been released, there should be no problem with rolling from 1.15.0 to a newer version, providing the Lucene version hasn't changed again. It might be better to instead check that there is no member older than the version in which Lucene was updated (1.15.0, assuming we don't cut the release branch before these changes are merged). I understand that this would be more work, and would mean that RollingUpgrade tests would become more complex, as they'd have to cover both the failing and passing cases, but if you agree that there would be value in only preventing Lucene queries when we know there's a potential problem rather than the more blunt approach currently used, then I'd appreciate the change.
> 
> Yes, there should no be a problem with rolling upgrade to a newer version once 1.15.0 is released, until there are no format changes in new Lucene versions.
> Maybe we can change tests to have some check to see if there is a member older than 1.15.0, and regarding the result run query or ignore it until all members are on a version where Lucene was updated, or newer.

Yeah, I think this would be the best course of action.

Well done Kirk!

some reasons I voted in favor of this:
- stress-new does not live up to its mission.  it stresses existing unchanged tests in addition to new tests (and it doesn't uncover newly-flaky tests that result from code changes in the product)
- we now have codeowners and weekly mass test runs, both of which provide a better gate/signal
- we have many other PR checks that are not required, and we seem to be doing fine with taking them under advice
for any revert (especially of a commit other than your own), a sentence or two about the motivation is always appreciated

What's the reasoning behind the rename of the package from "pubsub" to "publishAndSubscribe"? Also, it seems like you only renamed the packages in the "test", "integrationTest" and "acceptanceTest" submodules, but not "main" and "distributedTest." In addition, the 4 classes in the "acceptanceTest" submodule still have their package as "pubsub" in the files, despite being in the "publishAndSubscribe" directory.

> What's the reasoning behind the rename of the package from "pubsub" to "publishAndSubscribe"? Also, it seems like you only renamed the packages in the "test", "integrationTest" and "acceptanceTest" submodules, but not "main" and "distributedTest." In addition, the 4 classes in the "acceptanceTest" submodule still have their package as "pubsub" in the files, despite being in the "publishAndSubscribe" directory.

Thanks for catching all that-concentration has been  a little low this week :) 

As far as the rationale for the change goes:
When publlsh and subscribe functionality was originally introduced in our codebase, it was referred to as "pubsub" and a lot of stuff was named accordingly.  Now that we've added the specific command named "pubsub" it's unclear what the identifier "pubsub" refers to (the specific command, or the over all publish and subscribe functionality).  The rename is an attempt to untangle this and start a new convention of referring to the overall functionality by the full name and reserve the term "pubsub" for stuff related to the specific command by that name.  hit me up directly if you disagree with that idea, or want to discuss in more depth?

> > What's the reasoning behind the rename of the package from "pubsub" to "publishAndSubscribe"? Also, it seems like you only renamed the packages in the "test", "integrationTest" and "acceptanceTest" submodules, but not "main" and "distributedTest." In addition, the 4 classes in the "acceptanceTest" submodule still have their package as "pubsub" in the files, despite being in the "publishAndSubscribe" directory.

Now that we've added the specific command named "pubsub" it's unclear what the identifier "pubsub" refers to (the specific command, or the over all publish and subscribe functionality). The rename is an attempt to untangle this and start a new convention of referring to the overall functionality by the full name and reserve the term "pubsub" for stuff related to the specific command by that name. hit me up directly if you disagree with that idea, or want to discuss in more depth?
